I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed senior 
unsecured loan of $15,000,000 to DFCC Vardhana Bank (DVB) for the Housing Finance Project 
in Sri Lanka.1 
II.  THE FINANCIAL INTERMEDIARY 
A.  Investment Identification and Description 
2.  The finance sector in Sri Lanka has been constrained by a number of factors. The difficult 
investment climate, cumbersome procedures, and, in particular, the lack of access to adequate 
and timely financing has led to borrowing becoming more expensive and profit margins being 
reduced. Bank lending, however, has increased as a result of stabilization of the political situation 
and continued strengthening of the economy.  A gap in longer-term funding that would support 
the growing needs of borrowers seeking housing loans and funding for small and medium-sized 
enterprises (SMEs), for instance, remains. Moreover, there is a clear preference by banks to 
serve large, top-tier companies and higher-income customers that are perceived to have lower 
risks,  which  serves  to  further  limit  access  to  finance.  This  proposal  aims  to  support  the 
development of the finance sector by addressing the scarcity of housing finance in Sri Lanka by 
providing long-term funding and capacity building technical assistance (TA) to a mid-tier bank 
targeting the underserved market. 
 
3.  Sri Lanka suffers from a housing shortage that is currently estimated at between 350,000 
units and 1 million units with an additional need of about 100,000 units per annum.2 There is also 
a special need for new housing and rehabilitation of homes damaged by the civil war in the North 
and East, and South as a result of the 2004 tsunami. Demand for housing has steadily increased 
following the end of the civil war, which has led to improved consumer sentiment, rising income 
levels (16% in total since 2009),3 and repatriation of Sri Lankans.  
 
4.  Against this backdrop of growing demand, however, is a scarcity of mortgage financing as 
reflected in a mortgage debt–gross domestic product (GDP) ratio of 6%, which is considerably 
lower than the global average of about 30%. Although the Sri Lankan mortgage market grew at 
an annual rate of about 30% from 2004 to 2009, the World Bank estimates that 80% of the 
population does not have access to long-term financing needed to purchase homes (footnote 2). 
Not only is there a sheer lack of mortgage finance available, but also the small amount of 
mortgage finance that is provided is extended to just a few narrow customer segments, resulting 
in market fragmentation. The World Bank estimates that banks provide mortgages to only 20% of 
the population and at the higher end of the housing market, while a small segment of the lower 
end of the market is being served by microfinance institutions and some state-owned banks 
(footnote  2).  Nearly  30%  of  the  market,  primarily  in  the  middle-  and  lower-middle-income 
segments, are considered to be bankable clients but are not expected to be served in the near to 
medium term by the current market. The Government of Sri Lanka expects the private sector to 
play a larger role in the provision of housing finance and, with that, the government intends to 
shift away from primary mortgage provision. This will create further room for private commercial 
banks to expand their operations to cater to the largely unmet demand for housing finance.4

5.  A well-functioning mortgage system with increased and diverse private commercial bank 
participation in terms of first- and second-tier banks is needed to provide access to mortgage 
finance to these prospective borrowers and close the market gap. Greater private commercial 
bank  participation  is  expected  to  lead to  a more  competitive  mortgage finance market  with 
improved affordability, efficiencies, and product diversification, and, importantly, more inclusive 
customer segmentation strategies. The involvement of more private sector commercial banks 
providing higher volumes of mortgage lending (currently at only about 4% of total banking assets) 
is also important as the government cannot support the large needs of the housing market as it 
moves toward a more efficient economy.5 
 
6.  One of the primary impediments to the overall development of the mortgage market in Sri 
Lanka has been the lack of access to longer-term financing for banks because of the country’s 
low level of finance sector development (FSD) (specifically its capital markets), the civil war, and 
the global financial crisis. Due to the government’s current account deficit and the need to bridge 
the external funding gap, the government is encouraging overseas borrowings by Sri Lankan 
banks for both senior and subordinated debt.6 Other issues that have constrained growth include 
eviction difficulties, high land registration costs, the absence of an electronic title system, and lack 
of comprehensive market data.7 With respect to the middle- and lower-middle-income segments, 
additional  issues  include  a  perception  of  heightened  risk  (as  many of  these  customers  are 
nonsalaried workers), an absence or underdevelopment of sophisticated and specialized credit 
analysis  techniques  makes  it  difficult  for  banks  to  better  serve  these  markets,  and  lack  of 
affordability at the lower end of the market. 
 
7.  Given the need for long-term funding to increase private commercial bank participation in 
the market and with the goal of encouraging banks to target underserved customer segments, the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) met with several banks in 2011 to identify a suitable candidate 
with the interest and ability to move down market. Additionally, ADB sought a bank that could 
effectively address the specific needs for housing in the North, East, and South.  DVB, a medium-
sized bank and a participant in ADB’s Trade Finance Program,8 was selected as a partner bank 
for the project for a number of reasons. First, DVB has an interest in addressing underserved 
segments. Its current average mortgage loan size is approximately equivalent to $27,500, which 
is less than many of the larger banks. DVB is thus deploying a niche strategy by servicing an 
underserved segment of the market. Moreover, DVB is willing to move further down market with 
the use of ADB proceeds. Second, DVB’s parent bank, the DFCC, is a well-known development 
bank with over 60 years of experience in the market. DVB benefits from this brand recognition, 
which  is  particularly  important  for  personal  loans  such  as  mortgages.  Third,  DVB  has  an 
extensive branch network of 127 branches, of which 105 are outside Colombo, including eight in 
the North and East. Finally, although DVB is ranked eighth in the market in terms of assets 
($353.3 million as of 31 December 2011), its credit standing is close to or on par with some of the 
larger commercial banks. Fitch Ratings Sri Lanka has given DVB a AA- rating, which is equivalent 
to ratings for Hatton Bank and Sampath Bank and only one notch lower than Commercial Bank of 
Ceylon.9

8.  Project description. The project entails the provision of long-term funding of $15 million 
to  enable  DVB  to  provide  mortgages  to  borrowers  to  purchase  affordable  housing  and  to 
rehabilitate existing homes. The project has geographic targets to support rehabilitation in the 
North, East, and South. To strengthen the banking sector and enhance ADB’s developmental 
impact,  DVB  will  also  be  participating  in  ADB’s  existing  TA  for  Housing  Finance  Capacity 
Development in South and Southeast Asia to further strengthen its mortgage loan origination and 
servicing capacity.10 This will be the ADB Private Sector Operations Department’s first housing 
finance transaction in Sri Lanka. 
 
B.  Business Overview and Strategy 
9.  DVB is a subsidiary of DFCC and a licensed commercial bank.11 A merger between DFCC 
and DVB in the long term is possible, but this may be dependent on future amendments to the 
current Banking Act and CC being able to obtain a combined license/ commercial banking license 
with strong development banking links.12 In addition to its large branch network, DVB has 200 
automatic teller machines13 and 750 staff. At end December 2011, DVB had a 1.3% market share 
of total banking loans, 1.2% in terms of deposits, and 1.0% of total assets.14 DVB's lending focus 
has historically been the provision of working capital facilities to SMEs and corporate entities. 
DVB began providing housing loans in 2006; however, mortgage lending accelerated after the 
war in 2009. DVB established the Personal Financial Services Unit in 2010, which offers personal 
loans for professionals, mortgages and construction,15 education loans, financing of imports, and 
purchase of motor vehicles. As of the end of 2011, DVB’s portfolio was segmented as follows: 
corporate banking 22%, business banking 17%, branch banking and SMEs 50%, and personal 
financial services (PFS) 11%. 
 
10.  With the establishment of the Personal Financial Services Unit, DVB has strategically 
shifted to a customer-centered approach to better respond to growing consumer demands and 
the improving economy following the cessation of the civil war.16  By 2015, PFS is expected to 
contribute to 33% of all bank advances. DVB has launched a number of standard asset and 
liability products, such as leasing loans, education loans, and junior plus savings and deposits. 
With respect to its mortgage lending activities, to meet this target, DVB launched Vardhana 
Sandella, its branded housing loan product targeted at borrowers from business and professional 
backgrounds. DVB also benefits from its existing base of SME customers, as it is familiar with the 
market segment and can cross-sell its affordable home loan product to these potential borrowers. 
Second,  DVB  recruited  an  experienced  PFS  head  who  has  23  years  of  consumer  loan 
experience, including mortgage lending, from a leading bank in Sri Lanka. Third, DVB has further 
strengthened the SME department, enabling experienced staff to provide branches with expertise 
in areas including mortgage lending, and guidance as needed.  A separate mortgage finance unit 
will be created by the end of 2012. 
 
11.  The opening of the Northern and Eastern provinces is viewed by DVB as a  market 
opportunity, given the pent-up demand for financial services. DVB envisages an expanding role in

the post-conflict financing of this region through its increased network. By the end of 2012, DVB 
will add eight branches, giving DVB 16 branches in the North and East and by far the largest 
distribution network among the banks in Sri Lanka in the conflict-affected areas. Parallel to the

DVB’s expanded geographical penetration and increased number of staff enables it to market its 
PFS products to individual customers in rural and semi-urban areas, where competitors are not 
numerous. Eighty percent of DVB’s PFS portfolio is from the outstations.17 
 
C.  Ownership, Management, and Governance 
1.  Ownership 
12.  DVB, previously known as the National Mercantile Bank, was established as a licensed 
commercial bank in 1996. DFCC acquired the National Mercantile Bank in 2003 when it was in 
need  of  capital,  and  subsequently  restructured  and  renamed  it.  DFCC,  with  total  assets  of 
SLRs109.5 billion as of December 2011, is ranked fourth in the market as of 30 June 2011 in 
terms of total assets.18 DFCC currently holds a 99.1% stake in DVB.19 It obtained regulatory 
approval to increase its holding in DVB to 100% in April 2011. Major shareholders of DFCC are 
the Bank of Ceylon Pension Fund (14.3%), the Sri Lanka Insurance Corporation (13%), the 
Hatton National Bank (12%), M. Yaseen (8.6%),20 the Distilleries Company of Sri Lanka (6.4%), 
the  Seafeld  International  (5.76%),  and  the  Employees  Provident  Fund  (4.8%).21 DVB  is  of 
strategic importance to DFCC, accounting for 42% of DFCC’s assets as of the end of December 
2011, and plays an important role in expanding the group’s product offering. The two banks are 
viewed by DFCC as separate economic entities, but with integrated front- and most back-office 
functions. 
 
2.  Management 
13.  DVB’s senior management consists of a team of banking executives with experience 
across multiple banks in Sri Lanka and who are responsible for managing DVB in conformity with 
its stated goals. The key senior positions are (i) chief executive officer (CEO), (ii) chief operating 
officer, (iii) executive vice-president of lending, (iv) senior vice-president of treasury, (v) head of 
operations, (vi) senior vice-president of integrated risk management, (vii) vice-president of credit 
risk management and credit risk appraisal, and (viii) head of personal financial services. The 
CEO, L. Silva, has more than 25 years of experience in banking, credit, leasing, factoring, and 
branch management.22  The bank has a number of management committees.  The Asset Liability 
Committee (ALCO) analyzes DVB's operating condition and market risks, and devises strategies 
for  managing  risks  and  meeting  funding  needs.  The  ALCO  reports  to  the  Integrated  Risk 
Management Committee. 
 
3.  Governance Structure 
14.  DVB is managed through various levels of corporate governance, including the board of 
directors, several board committees to facilitate managing DVB's operations, and the internal and 
external audit function. The board of directors reports to the shareholders and is headed by its

by a board of directors comprising 10 members, of whom four are independent. Apart from the 
chair and CEO of DFCC, DVB, and DFCC have different board members. They come from 
various backgrounds and have diverse experience both locally and internationally. The board 
approves DVB's strategy, business plan, and corporate plan; reviews all of DVB's general policies

Committee,  the  Integrated  Risk  Management  Committee,  and  the  Nomination  Committee. 
Compliance within DVB is supervised by the Audit Committee, which reports to the board.  
 
D.  Financial Performance

SLRs29.5 billion to SLRs45.9 billion from 2010 to 2011. As of the end of March 2012, total assets 
were SLRs52.9 billion. Growth in net income was 92% from 2010 to 2011, which is strong given 
the competitive interest rate environment and DVB’s increased branch network costs. Table 1 
provides a summary of DVB’s financial performance from 2008 through 2011.

16.  Capital adequacy. DVB’s capital position is strong at 17.2% of risk-weighted assets as of 
the end of 2011. This is an improvement from 15.4% as of the end of 2010, which was due to 
fresh capital infusion of SLRs1.1 billion from the parent company by way of a rights issue and a 
fully subscribed SLRs1.0 billion subordinated debenture issue in 2011. 
 
17.  Asset quality. DVB’s nonperforming loan (NPL) ratio, defined as 90 days and above past 
due, was 4.3% as of the end of 2011, below the industry average of 4.5% and comparing 
favorably to the NPL ratio of 7.2% reported at the end of 2010. Housing NPLs were low at only 
2% as of March 2012. The overall improvement of the quality of the credit portfolio reflects the 
benefits of stable economic conditions and DVB’s concerted actions to reduce NPLs by tightening 
credit underwriting standards.

18.  Earnings. Operational costs have increased due to branch network growth, upgrading of 
management information systems, and the recruitment of additional staff. However, profits still 
remained  robust.  After-tax  earnings  increased  by  92%  from  SLRs275.9  million  in  2010  to 
SLRs531.4 million in 2011 in line with the increase in DVB’s lending portfolio, which grew from 
about SLRs19 billion in 2010 to SLRs33 billion in 2011. The increase in net profit was driven by 
growth in fund- and fee-based income, cost efficiencies relating to operations, and reduced loan 
impairment charges. Net income during the three months ending 31 March 2012 was SLRs150.7 
million. 
 
19.  Liquidity. DVB has diversified sources of funds. During 2011, DVB was able to borrow 
shorter-term funds from commercial banks and raise capital from the market. DVB’s loan–deposit 
ratio increased from 91% to 104% from 2010 to 2011as deposits grew more slowly than loans. 
There were negative maturity gaps in the 3–6-month bucket due to deposit maturities, as more 
depositors prefer a shorter investment horizon when there is an upward movement in the yield 
curve, and in the above 5-year bucket due to the shortage of longer-term financing, which is 
required for some of the longer-term products such as mortgage loans. ADB’s 10-year loan will 
help to reduce maturity mismatches for longer-term mortgage loans.24 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
A.  The Assistance 
 
20. ADB proposes to provide a senior unsecured loan to DVB of $15 million with a tenor of 10 
years. DVB will be required to use the facility exclusively for mortgage onlending and housing 
rehabilitation loans. The ADB loan will be disbursed in two tranches to help DVB better manage 
its growth and to benefit from ADB’s TA for Housing Finance Capacity Development in South and 
Southeast Asia (footnote 10).The capacity development TA will focus on (i) improving credit 
assessment techniques with a particular emphasis on assessing self-employed or lower-middle-
income borrowers, which comprise part of the target market of the project; (ii) developing a more 
detailed  scorecard  for  housing  loan  borrowers  and  portfolio  and  risk  management;  and  (iii) 
training. 
 
21.  Housing loan parameters for the ADB facility. ADB will restrict the use of its funds to 
only owner-occupied residences to prevent speculative lending. Additionally, a geographic target 
will be set at a minimum of 30% outside Colombo in the North, East, and tsunami-impacted 
areas. To ensure that DVB is providing loans for affordable housing, it will be expected to have an 
average mortgage loan size of not more than $20,000 for the pool of mortgages originated from 
ADB funds. This represents a reduction of about 25% from DVB’s current average mortgage loan 
size. Additionally, to ensure prudent growth of the portfolio, loan-to–value ratios in excess of 80% 
will not be allowed. 
 
B.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  Reporting arrangements. DVB will be required to provide the following information: (i) 
unaudited quarterly financial statements; (ii) audited annual financial statements; (iii) quarterly 
compliance  certificates  for  agreed-upon  financial  covenants;  (iv)  semiannual  reports  on  the 
mortgage portfolio, which will include data on loans extended to women; and (v) an annual 
environmental  and  social  performance  report,  including  a report  on  housing  loans taken  by 
women. Pursuant to ADB’s Operations Manual governing, Nonsovereign Operations, monitoring 
reports will be prepared on a regular basis, but at least annually. 25 The first monitoring report will 
be prepared no later than 12 months after approval by the ADB Board of Directors.

C.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
23.  ADB will provide critically needed long-term funding to DVB, which DVB can in turn use to 
offer mortgages of longer tenor. Housing borrowers in Sri Lanka have been adversely impacted 
by the country’s low level of FSD (especially in the North and East), including the absence of a 
well-developed capital market, which limits the availability of longer-tenor funding. In addition, 
ADB’s involvement ensures that the loan will be used to target housing finance needs in areas 
impacted by the civil war and tsunami. With the recovery and the return of the diaspora, longer-
tenor funding is essential to build or rebuild houses that have been destroyed or damaged, and to 
support future growth. Moreover, women who have lost their spouses in the war will also have the 
opportunity to borrow and build secure housing and/or improve existing dwellings. DVB has 
committed  to  provide  5%  of  the  facility  to  women  borrowers.  Lastly,  the  ADB  capacity 
development TA will provide DVB with support to prudently expand and increase the efficiency 
and sustainability of services for mortgage lending. Increasing efficiencies is expected to enable 
DVB to improve affordability of mortgage loans.26 
 
D.  Risks 
24.  Political and economic conditions. President Rajapaksa’s coalition party has ruled for 
two consecutive terms since the end of the war. While the rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam 
is not expected to reemerge as a major threat, isolated terrorist attacks may occur. In addition, 
although the economy has been strengthening since 2009, it has been affected by the global 
downturn and high interest rates due to a lack of liquidity in the banking system.27 Adverse 
changes in the political situation or a further economic downturn could negatively impact DVB’s 
overall performance, as well as the demand for mortgage loans. However, Sri Lanka’s overall 
outlook is positive and GDP is projected to expand by 7% annually (footnote 26) on average 
through 2016. 
 
25.  Regulatory issues pertaining to mortgage lending. The Sri Lankan title registration 
system and regulatory environment for mortgage lending could be strengthened to accelerate 
housing ownership.  Regulatory issues have not constrained growth of DVB’s housing finance 
business.  Banks can foreclose on property, but eviction is culturally difficult.  In the north and 
east, there are titling issues in certain cities as a result of the civil conflict.  DVB will carefully 
assess titling and registration issues in these regions.  In many cases where clear titles are an 
issue, DVB can obtain title insurance. 
 
26.  Market competition. The housing finance market in Sri Lanka has become increasingly 
competitive since 2009, particularly in specific market segments. State-owned banks, helped by 
the offering of subsidized lending to not only low-income borrowers but also middle-income 
borrowers, continue to dominate the housing finance market. However, DVB as well as other mid-
tier banks are seeking to build their housing loan portfolios. While DVB currently operates in the 
upper middle- and middle-income market, DVB seeks to capitalize on its niche SME market 
knowledge and broad distribution network to expand into other income and geographic segments, 
now largely underserved, which is expected to give it a strategic advantage. The government is 
also not expected to be able to continue to provide large subsidies to state-owned banks on a 
long-term basis, which should contribute to leveling the playing field.

8    
27.  Portfolio growth, evolving risk management/underwriting capacity. DVB reported an 
NPL ratio of 4.3% in 2011, a decrease of 2.9% from 2010, coinciding with total loan growth of 
75% in 2011. DVB’s mortgage loan portfolio has also performed well with an NPL ratio of 2% as 
of 31 March 2012. DVB has implemented a number of measures to improve credit underwriting 
and portfolio monitoring standards including the use of a risk rating tool, sector segmentation, and 
increasing down payments when necessary. In the near term, the bank plans to further tailor its 
credit scoring system for mortgage lending.  ADB’s TA will help to further strengthen DVB’s credit 
underwriting and servicing standards to help the bank manage its expansion in this market 
segment. Additionally, ADB’s loan will be provided in two tranches to prudently manage loan 
origination. ADB will monitor asset quality via reporting from DVB on the bank and its mortgage 
portfolio.  
 
28.  Future funding risk. Growth of DVB's mortgage business is dependent upon access to 
long-term funding and deposit growth, which are constrained by the state of the capital markets 
and macroeconomic instability. Banks can access capital markets, but the tenor of bonds tends to 
be shorter term. In the future, as the capital markets mature, banks may be able to issue longer-
term bonds. More immediately, longer-term funding can be obtained through other IFIs active in 
Sri Lanka. DFCC has relationships with various IFls and has been successful in obtaining funding 
from them.  
 
29.  Currency risk. DVB will borrow and repay in US dollars, although all mortgage loans will 
be in Sri Lanka rupees. To mitigate this risk, DVB will hedge the ADB loan and the Central Bank 
of Sri Lanka has offered swaps at preferred rates for all banks obtaining foreign funds. DVB is 
compliant with the prudential open exposure limit of a daily maximum of $3 million. As of the end 
of December 2011, DVB had an open exposure of $2.6 million. As DVB’s treasury operations are 
integrated with DFCC, DFCC will help DVB to hedge open exposures. Currently, there are no 
viable currency swap options via ADB, and ADB does not have the ability to issue a local 
currency bond. Should this scenario change during the tenor of the loan, DVB will have the option 
to convert the loan on agreed terms with ADB. 
IV.  DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 
A.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
30.  The project will directly contribute to private commercial banks, especially tier-two banks, 
having an increased share in the housing finance sector in Sri Lanka, which is important given 
that state-owned banks have the dominant share of the market. Increasing the private sector’s 
share of the housing finance market from 36% to 46% by supporting the growth of mid-tier banks 
is expected to improve competition in the sector and lead to the development of competitive 
pricing and better products and services. It is also expected to help address housing shortages, 
given that, as more mortgage financing becomes available for affordable housing, construction in 
this segment typically grows.28 Other indirect development impacts of housing finance include an 
increased contribution of the construction sector to overall economic growth and employment 
generation, particularly for unskilled or nonprofessional or technical workers, through its many 
backward and forward linkages.29 The main outcome from the project is the successful expansion 
of DVB’s housing finance program to an underserved segment, while ensuring a minimum 30% of 
the amount equal to the ADB loan is provided as mortgage loans in the North, East, and South by

2017. DVB will also commit to providing at least a 5% of the amount equal to the ADB loan to 
female mortgage borrowers  and at least 40% of the amount equal to the ADB loan to married 
couples (jointly to husbands and wives) by the end of 2017.  The output includes DVB having 
increased  housing  finance  from  DVB.  A  key  output  of  the  TA  will  be  improved  credit  risk 
assessment and servicing capabilities to better target more lower-income clients. The latter is a 
result of the parallel CDTA approved in 2009 by ADB for capacity development for housing 
finance, some resources from which will be specifically directed to DVB to enable it to improve 
the quality of its growing housing portfolio. DVB will also commit to a target of training 50% of its 
female credit analysts with funding from the CDTA. 
 
B.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 
31.  Under Strategy 2020, ADB will strengthen its support to the finance sector at the regional 
and national levels by helping to develop financial infrastructure, institutions, and products and 
services and by promoting inclusive growth.30 Through such initiatives, ADB will continue to assist 
in channeling the region's savings into the most productive investments, as well as continue to 
build  the  capacity  of  financial  institutions  by  introducing  international  best  practices.  The 
investment supports institutional and finance sector development through the deepening of the 
finance sector by expanding mortgage lending in Sri Lanka to an underserved customer segment.  
 
32.  The  project  is  also  consistent  with  the  government’s  10-year  development  policy 
framework (DPF), 2007–2016, and ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2012–2016.31 The DPF 
was revised in 2010, reflecting the change in the country’s environment after the end of the war. It 
aims to accelerate economic growth, increase access to finance, address low private sector 
investment,  improve  social  indicators,  eradicate  hard-core  poverty,  and  improve  the 
environment.32 The country partnership strategy is built on the DPF and Strategy 2020, which 
specifies a focus of ADB assistance on private sector development and expanding the role of the 
private sector, including projects that support housing. The project supports both these objectives 
by  increasing  the  share  of  private  commercial financing  in the  housing finance market  and 
improving bank capacity in this area through TA. 
 
2.  Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations 
33.  Supporting FSD is a key focus of development assistance for ADB, in line with the tenets 
of ADB's Private Sector Development Strategy (footnote 32) and enhanced poverty reduction 
strategy.33 The latter states that ADB seeks to promote ―sound and efficient banking systems and 
capital markets‖ since these are seen as ―indispensable for macroeconomic stability, mobilizing 
savings and ensuring availability of long term financing, an essential requirement for pro-poor 
growth‖ (footnote 33). ADB's Private Sector Development Strategy refers specifically to ADB's 
role  in  strengthening  the  finance  sector,  including  housing  finance,  in  developing  member 
countries. ADB’s Capital Markets and Financial Sectors Division’s Business Plan and Priorities, 
2010–201234 also states that ADB will support housing finance projects as one of the major 
components for a healthy finance sector. In addition, ADB’s Finance Sector Operational Plan 
highlights the need to support housing finance projects as part of FSD in developing member

countries.35 This facility will help strengthen the finance sector in Sri Lanka by enabling a private

V.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
34.  The investment is classified category FI treated as C for impacts on the environment, 
involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. DVB’s business activities have minimal or no 
adverse environmental impacts, and are unlikely to entail impacts on involuntary resettlement and 
indigenous peoples. DVB will apply ADB's prohibited investment activities list, exclude all projects 
that will have adverse environment and social safeguards impacts, ensure that investments using 
ADB funds abide by applicable national laws and regulations and comply with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement (2009). DVB will confirm this in its periodic reports to ADB and need not apply 
any other specific safeguard requirements.36 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
35.  DVB was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practices relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
36.  The proposed senior unsecured loan is within the medium-term country, industry, group, 
and single investment exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D.  Assurances 
37.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),37 
the Government of Sri Lanka will be requested to confirm that it has no objection to the proposed 
assistance to DVB. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance 
satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
VI.  RECOMMENDATION 
38.  I am satisfied that the proposed senior unsecured loan would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
loan of $15,000,000 to DFCC Vardhana Bank for the Housing Finance Project in Sri Lanka, from 
ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  such  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda
